{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3616938,"name":"Owen Tharp","username":"Grumpy_Bud","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/e274bd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-08T15:34:58.571Z","cooked":"

Our robot uses a rev color sensor v3 for proximity detection, as it what we had in the lab. It faces up looking for coral, and when proximity is greater than 120 there is a boolean flipped. It seemed like everything was working fine, until practice match one at SMR. Suddenly, our elevator and arm began to jerk erratically out of nowhere. We checked the log files, but didn’t notice anything off at first. So, we continued our matches noticing no issues after. We figured it was just a random issue that likely wouldn’t happen again, until one of our last practice matches:

Match video

As you can see, it goes from behaving normally to jerking up and down. Checking the log, we this time checked the code cycle times (we use advantagekit for our logging). We saw a sudden jump from around 9 ms loop time to over 500 instantly. No slow buildup, no variables changed, it just shot up. 80ms went to autologms, and the rest were in Robot.periodic. We figured it mightve been due to the i2c port, but the FTAs mentioned that generally causes a crash, not just lag. Since we had little idea, we removed some simulation code to make sure it wasn’t running on the real robot, and continued on.

Screenshot 2025-05-08 at 11.25.21 AM1998×1726 288 KB

Now, moving to CMP. Match 112, the robot did the same thing. This time, we had implemented a “loggedTracer” which told us exactly which loop was causing the lag.

Match video

It reported that intake.java was the source of our troubles. Funnily enough, this is where the rev color sensor is defined. We have a very simple intake file, literally just setting two motor voltages and the color sensor boolean. We are at a loss, since this event is barely reproducible and there are no consistent factors between the lag and events in the code. Here was the code running on the robot at the time of match 112, although it may be slightly ahead: 1466 Github

The only change not yet one the robot is shown here, so it could have been the problem. However, its hard to tell if this has changed anything:

Screenshot 2025-05-08 at 11.32.51 AM2330×1204 360 KB

If anyone has any ideas, we would be incredibly grateful. If I missed any information, just let me know.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-05-08T15:34:58.571Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":277,"readers_count":276,"score":70.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":501427,"topic_slug":"over-30x-loop-overrun-seemingly-randomly","display_username":"Owen Tharp","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://drive.google.com/file/d/1K4xblWspfcI38gLuBLtmgtD4iYuREK5O/view?usp=sharing&t=22","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"IMG_1171.MOV - Google Drive","clicks":4},{"url":"https://github.com/FRC1466/robot-code-2025/tree/testing-algae-pickup-approach%2C-not-correct-yet","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - FRC1466/robot-code-2025 at testing-algae-pickup-approach,-not-correct-yet","clicks":3},{"url":"https://youtu.be/q6kdpm6JSyM?t=99","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68308,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/over-30x-loop-overrun-seemingly-randomly/501427/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3616974,"name":"Nolan Barker","username":"therekrab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/therekrab/{size}/248500_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-08T16:29:52.875Z","cooked":"

To me, the intake subsystem looks fine. I don’t see what the issue(s) could be if they’re actually originating from there. However, I’m skeptical that your LoggedTracer is accurately reporting all the things.

If I’m understanding the CommandScheduler docs correctly, each periodic method is ran in sequence. That means that if one subsystem or command takes a long time to run, the LoggedTracker will take a while to update the time, making it look like a different subsystem is responsible.

Detailed Explanation

Consider a very basic robot, with two Subsystems: drivetrain and elevator.

Each command scheduler iteration, the periodic() method is called on each subsystem. Let’s say these go smoothly (very low execution time).
However, if a command is running, that command’s execute (or initialize, end, and/or isFinished) gets ran before the scheduler runs again. What this means is that is the last subsystem will call LoggedTracer.record, which sets the current time as the last time.

Then we run a command - teleop drive, for example. But we’ve made a logic bug, and that command takes a while to execute. Then, it can cause these loop overruns we’re seeing.

However, the next iteration of the command scheduler will visit each subsystem first. Let’s say it visits drivetrain first. It calls drivetrain’s periodic() method, and that runs normally. But, at the end, the method LoggedTracer.record() is called. Because it’s been a while since the method has been called (that command took forever, remember?), the entire amount of time it’s been is attributed to the drivetrain subsystem - which isn’t necessarily accurate.

Another possible reason to inaccurately identify the intake as the “slow” subsystem is inconsistent calls to LoggedTracer.record(). For example, in your code’s drivetrain, the method is never used. This means that if the drivetrain’s periodic is slow, that time gap gets attributed to the next subsystem - which could be the intake.

Both of these two issues could cause a subsystem (intake in your case) to be misidentified as the subsystem that takes a while.

I’ll keep looking into the issue, but I don’t think that the intake is actually the issue. Please let me know if I misunderstood anything or was just plain wrong (I’m no expert on the command scheduler, I’m just trying to understand the docs).

For now, here’s what I would do to better track the individual cycle times of each subsystem’s periodic call:

My approach

I would replace the singleton LoggedTracer with a logged tracer for each subsystem, and call reset at the start of periodic and then record at the end. This more accurately tracks the amount of time that each periodic method takes, versus the amount of time since the last call to record.

Several teams over the last few years have reported issues with the Rio I2C / Rev color sensor causing very long delays (in the 100s of ms range), not just system lockups. Moving the I2C sensor to an alternative (eg a Pi Pico using GitHub - ThadHouse/picocolorsensor: Rev V3 Library for Raspberry Pi Pico) is a good way to work around this issue.

We moved the I2C read to a separate thread in 2022. Does that effectively mitigate the problem also, as the I2C thread could lag, but your robot code can run on the other core with no issues?
